<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 255, 920, 308]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>

<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 663, 89]]<|/det|>
An isotope of boron is used in the treatment of cancer in the brain.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 102, 448, 120]]<|/det|>
Boron sticks to cancer cells in the brain.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
The isotope of boron is bombarded with neutrons then undergoes fission to form lithium and alpha-particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 180, 181, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 623, 199]]<|/det|>
Describe **one** difference between fission and fusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 272, 181, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
A nucleus of boron (B) contains 5 protons and 5 neutrons. Complete the nuclide equation for this fission reaction.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 323, 690, 355]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{c}{...........}\\ {...........} \end{array}\mathsf{B} + \mathrm{~}^{1}\mathrm{n}\rightarrow \mathrm{~}^{...........}\mathrm{~Li} + \mathrm{~}^{...........}\mathrm{~}\alpha\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 352, 920, 371]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 146, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 381, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
The alpha-particles destroy the cancer cells. Suggest and explain **one** reason why alpha particles are more suitable than gamma radiation for use in this treatment of brain cancer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 521, 144, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
Other cancers are treated with gamma radiation. Describe **one** safety precaution a nurse or radiologist takes during this treatment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 345, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
Hydrogen in a very distant galaxy emits electromagnetic radiation which is observed on the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 392, 920, 426]]<|/det|>
Scientists on the Earth measure the wavelength of the radiation from the very distant galaxy. The wavelength is \(918 \text{nm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
On the Earth, hydrogen in the laboratory emits electromagnetic radiation of wavelength \(656 \text{nm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 469, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
Name the effect that the scientists observe and state what this shows about the very distant galaxy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 577, 920, 596]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|> Table 9.1 shows a wavelength of electromagnetic radiation from hydrogen observed in the laboratory and from three galaxies. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 601, 135]]<|/det|> The galaxies are at different distances from the Earth. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 149, 539, 166]]<|/det|> Table 9.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 180, 845, 316]]<|/det|>

gas tube in laboratory656
nearby galaxy667
distant galaxy750
very distant galaxy918
